title: First uncountable ordinal
summary: In mathematics, the first uncountable ordinal, traditionally denoted by ω 1 {\displaystyle \omega _{1}} or sometimes by Ω {\displaystyle \Omega } , is the smallest ordinal number that, considered as a set, is uncountable. It is the supremum (least upper bound) of all countable ordinals. When considered as a set, the elements of ω 1 {\displaystyle \omega _{1}} are the countable ordinals (including finite ordinals),[1] of which there are uncountably many.
